text:
A close friend of the great Ming literatus, Tung Ch'i-ch'ang (1555-1636), Ch'en Chi-ju (1558-1639) came from relatively humble family origins. Having obtained the hsiu-ts'ai degree at twenty-eight, he shunned government service and lived the life of a reclusive literatus. Highly regarded in official and scholarly circles, his fame was based on his writing, art collecting, and refined lifestyle.

This sparse landscape makes pointed reference to the style and techniques of the great fourteenth-century master Ni Tsan (1301-74). Ni's dry, delicate, personal brushwork had tremendous influence on later literati artists. The deliberate sparseness of his rarified compositions, spare use of ink, and dry texture strokes that defined his landscapes are clearly evident here in Ch'en's homage to the earlier scholar-painter.
title: Landscape in the Style of Ni Tsan
